DOC.brief_summary: Ertapenem is an antibiotic that is highly bound to plasma protein (> 95%). The effects of this high protein binding on tissue distribution of antibiotics have been few evaluated yet. In this study, two groups of subjects will be compared: 6 healthy volunteers and 6 critically ill patients (patients with infection due to an Ertapenem susceptible bacteria). Indeed, these 2 populations show changes in binding capacity of drugs to plasma proteins due to a decrease of protidaemia and of the affinity of drugs to transport proteins. It seems therefore important to clarify the consequences of a modification in protein binding on distribution of antibiotics. That's why we have decided to characterize tissue distribution of ertapenem in healthy volunteers and critically ill patients by assessing: free and total concentrations in plasma and free concentrations in muscle by microdialysis.
DOC.brief_title: Comparison of Ertapenem Distribution in the Muscle of Six Healthy Volunteers and Six Critically Ill Patients by Microdialysis
DOC.criteria: Age: from 18 to 80 years Patients with infection due to ertapenem susceptible bacteria. Patients who received ertapenem within 7 days prior to inclusion Known allergy to ertapenem or any excipients Neutropenia < 500/mm3 Hemoglobin concentration < 9g/dl Renal failure (creatinin clearance < 30ml/min/1.73m²) Decompensated heart failure Patients receiving vasopressor (adrenalin, noradrenalin), > 0.5µg/kg/min Known hypersensitivity to Elma® Positive pregnancy test or currently lactating
DOC.keyword: patients infected with a bacteria sensible to ertapeneme
